A couple of very mundane points:

Go for RMI over IIOP from the start - its easy using the POA in  
recent CORBA. My experience of RMI under load is that it's a bit  
flaky and what's worse is that its 'flaky' as opposed to right out  
breaking so you find the odd call not happening properly. I did a  
fair amount of load testing on it and decided that it was  
rubbish :-). I also load tested RMI over IIOP and couldn't manage to  
load it enough to break it at all.

I've used JMS in JBoss quite a lot too and you might find that it  
provides a good way of providing resilience as machines come and go.  
I can't remember the ins and outs but from what I remember one of the  
configurations don't cope well with lots of small messages though.

For dynamic configuration of the server farm have you considered  
JINI. Its a really nice technology for this kind of thing - you can  
add and remove components from a large system in a true 'plug and  
play' fashion. Its a little bit fiddley to get working with 'pure'  
J2EE but you can make it work in JBoss.

cheers

mark
